title.narrative: KATO-RANI Women Cotton Value Chain Initv

description.narrative:
KATO- RANI# An All Women Cotton Value Chain Initiative (Advocacy <(>&<)> Awareness Campaign)
Project Information:
Advocacy and awareness campaign on the safe use of pesticides is a component of the larger project #Kato Rani#
Objectives of the project:
To influence government policies and practices in favour of women farmers and against the indiscriminate use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides
Key Activities:
Three dialogues/Kisan Bethaks of duty bearers with stake holders including government, Fertilizer/ Pesticide companies, Civil Society Organisations and Media related persons. Ten FM radio programs focusing on harmful effects and health hazards of unsafe use of fertilizers and pesticides particularly on women cotton growers. Layout and Designing of Pictorial IEC material on health hazards of unsafe use of pesticides on cotton pickers particularly women. Ten Awareness raising sessions at FO/ PO level about the harmful effects and health hazards of unsafe use of fertilizers and pesticides. Organizing Besakhi festival in the project area in addition to observing Labor Day, World Food Day and Water Day for support and solidarity among stakeholders.
Outcome:
A consensus built among the farmers, civil society, media, government andPesticide/ Fertilizer companies in the private sector aboutthe need to develop a mechanism for the safe use of fertilizers and pesticides.

participating-org.narrative:
Sojhla for Social Change as active part of peace movement in Pakistan as well as in South Asian Region was a partner in the Oxfam Novib#s Campaign #Peace My Right# and is currently an implementing partner in Citizens First project. Sojhla has also supported, local partners, in certain activities related to sustainable agriculture conducted by Oxfam#s Grow Campaign. Sojhla contributed all deliberations with relevant inputs and suggestions.
Sojhla for Social Change started working in 2002 with its set objectives regarding peace, gender mainstreaming and governance. However later on realizing the community needs it included the areas for intervention such as girls' education, livelihood as well as health preventive and curative measures through awarenessand primary level services. The focus of advocacy intervention areas by Sojhla mainly remained around promotion of primary education specially for girl child, livelihood promotion in flood and water logging area based on backward and forward linkages, women empowerment for self-reliant through Self-help group formation <(>&<)> cluster development, reduce the violent behaviour, domestic violence, children specially adolescent girl, creating employment opportunities through providing awareness regarding their skills and supporting their approach to markets, supported women farmers to raise their voice through collective interventions etc.
Sojhla has networking and interaction with national level advocacy groups and support organizations including peace, food security <(>&<)> climate change movements in South Asia. Sojhla actively participated in Pesticide Asia Network-Asia Pacific(PAN-AP), Civil Society Platform for Development and Effectiveness(CPDE), South Asian Peace initiatives. In addition it is observed fromSojhla reports that it has engaged relevant stake holdersin the campaigns and advocacy initiatives. The important strength of Sojhla is visible from its reports about its linkages and interaction with community groups. Cultural action is also important component of Sojhla strategy.
